0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Lipodystrophy associated with Human immunodeficiency virus infection: 2 mg SUBQ once daily in the abdomen; rotate abdominal injection sites

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in children

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Lipodystrophy associated with Human immunodeficiency virus infection

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis due to hypophysectomy, hypopituitarism, pituitary tumor/surgery, or head irradiation or trauma
  • hypersensitivity to tesamorelin and/or mannitol
  • malignancy, active (either newly diagnosed or recurrent); malignancies should be inactive and completely treated prior to initiating therapy
  • pregnancy; may cause fetal harm

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute respiratory failure or acute critical illness (due to complications following multiple accidental trauma or open-heart or abdominal surgery); increased risk of mortality following growth hormone therapy
  • children with open epiphyses; risk of linear growth acceleration and excessive growth
  • diabetes; risk of new or worsening retinopathy due to increases in insulin-like growth factor 1; monitoring recommended
  • glucose intolerance may occur; monitoring recommended
  • hypersensitivity reactions (eg, pruritus, erythema, flushing, urticaria, and other rash) have been reported
  • insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) elevations have been reported, some within 13 weeks of treatment; monitoring recommended; consider discontinuing therapy for persistent elevations (eg, greater than 3 standard deviation scores)
  • malignancy, history of treated and stable; risk of reactivation of underlying malignancy due to induction of endogenous growth hormone
  • nonmalignant neoplasms, history; induction of endogenous growth hormone may increase the risk of neoplasm
  • report suspected adverse reactions to EMD Serono at 1-800-283-8088 ext. 5563 or to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Tesamorelin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Peripheral edema (2% to 6.1%)
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (1.2% to 8.5%), Injection site irritation (2.9%), Injection site pain (4.1%), Injection site pruritus (2% to 7.6%), Injection site reaction (1.3% to 24.5%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Serum insulin-like growth factor 1 measurement, elevated (33.7% to 47.4%)
  • Immunologic:Antibody development (47.4% to 49.5%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (13.3%), Pain, Extremity (3.3% to 6.1%)
  • Neurologic:Carpal tunnel syndrome (1.5%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Tesamorelin acetate, an analog of human growth hormone (GH)-releasing factor, stimulates GH secretion which increases insulin-like growthfactor-I (IGF-I) and insulin-like growth factor-binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3) levels.

1.title: Distribution
1.mono:
• Vd, healthy subjects: 9.4 L/kg
  • Vd, HIV-infected patients: 10.5 L/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • Add 2.2 mL of the supplied diluent to the contents of the first 1-mg vial; reconstitute by rolling between hands for 30 seconds; do not shake.
  • Add the contents of the reconstituted first vial to a second 1-mg vial; reconstitute by rolling between hands for 30 seconds; do not shake; use immediately.
  • Do not freeze or refrigerate the reconstituted solution; if not used immediately, discard the reconstituted solution.
  • Recommended injection site is the abdomen; rotate injection sites; avoid injecting into scar tissue, bruises, or the navel.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduction in visceral adipose tissue by waist circumference or CT scan measurement is indicative of efficacy
  • insulin-like growth factor-1 levels; during therapy
  • glucose metabolism changes; periodically in all patients
  • retinopathy, new-onset or worsening of; regularly in patients with diabetes

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause arthralgia, myalgia, fluid retention, injection site reactions (eg, erythema, pruritus, pain, irritation, and bruising), and alteration in glucose tolerance.
  • Advise patients with diabetes to report new-onset or worsening retinopathy.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of hypersensitivity (eg, pruritus, erythema, flushing, urticaria, or other rash).
  • Teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
  • Advise patient to rotate injection sites.
